setting.description: 6:47 AM. The SAT prep book has been open to the same page for twenty minutes.

narrative.text: Downstairs, you hear Ma and Ba in the kitchen. The smell of congee drifts up. Lily is probably already at the table.

narrative.speaker: Ma
narrative.text: Alex! Breakfast is ready! Come eat before school!

options.text: Go downstairs for breakfast
options.internal_monologue: (The congee is better warm. The vocabulary words will still be there.)

options.text: Five more minutes ‚Äî just need to finish this section
options.internal_monologue: (You hear Ma set a bowl outside your door twenty minutes later. It's cold by the time you notice.)

setting.description: The fluorescent lights hum. Your locker combination is muscle memory.

narrative.text: Dev is waiting by your locker. He's got that look ‚Äî the one where he's about to tell you his practice SAT score.

narrative.speaker: Dev
narrative.text: Bro. 1480. I'm so close to 1500. What'd you get?

options.text: Tell him honestly ‚Äî you haven't taken the practice test yet
options.internal_monologue: (Dev doesn't judge. That's why he's your best friend. But you judge yourself enough for both of you.)

options.text: "Same range. Still grinding." (You got a 1390.)
options.internal_monologue: (The lie comes easy. That's the part that scares you.)

setting.description: 9:30 PM. The house is quiet. Ba is watching the news in the other room.

narrative.text: Lily is doing homework at the kitchen table. She looks up when you walk in.

narrative.speaker: Lily
narrative.text: Alex, can you help me with math? Mrs. Patterson gave us these problems and I don't‚Äî

options.text: Sit down and help her
options.internal_monologue: (She gets it on the third try. The smile on her face is worth more than a vocabulary word.)

options.text: "Ask Ba, I have to study."
options.internal_monologue: (From your room, you hear Ba trying to explain fractions. His English stumbles on the word 'denominator.' Lily says 'It's okay, Ba.' You put your headphones on.)

setting.description: 7:15 AM. Ba drives you to school. The taxi meter is covered with a cloth.

narrative.text: Ba's hands are on the wheel at 10 and 2. He was an engineer back home. Now he knows every shortcut in the city.

narrative.speaker: Ba
narrative.text: How is studying? SAT is coming, yes?

options.text: "It's good, Ba. I'm working hard."
options.internal_monologue: (Ba nods. He doesn't say 'I'm proud of you.' He doesn't have to. The way he adjusted his mirror to see you better says it.)

options.text: "Ba, do you ever miss being an engineer?"
options.internal_monologue: (Ba is quiet for a long time. Then: 'I drive taxi so you don't have to.' He pulls up to school. 'Have good day.' His voice cracks on the last word.)

setting.description: The whiteboard is covered in strategies. 'Eliminate obviously wrong answers.'

narrative.text: The instructor is going through reading comprehension. You've seen this passage three times. Dev is highlighting everything.
Your phone buzzes under the desk. It's from Lily: a photo of a drawing she made. It's you, with a graduation cap that's too big.

options.text: Smile, text back a heart emoji, then focus on the lesson
options.internal_monologue: (You can be both. You can do both. That's what you tell yourself.)

options.text: Put the phone away without responding ‚Äî you'll text later
options.internal_monologue: (You forget to text back. You always forget to text back.)

setting.description: Ma made your favorite. Ba's friends are over. The air smells like ginger and comparison.

narrative.text: Uncle Chen's son got into a summer program at MIT. Auntie Li's daughter scored a 1560. The table is a scoreboard disguised as a dinner party.

narrative.speaker: Ma
narrative.text: Alex is studying very hard. Top of the class. We are very proud.
Ma looks at you. There's pride in her eyes. But also: pressure. A prayer. A plea.

options.text: Smile and perform. This is for them.
options.internal_monologue: (You recite your GPA, your extracurriculars, your plan. You sound like a college brochure. Everyone nods. You hate how good it feels.)

options.text: "I'm doing fine." Change the subject to Lily's drawing.
options.internal_monologue: (Lily lights up when you show the drawing. The adults lose interest. Ma gives you a look that says: 'You could have tried harder for them.' But Lily is beaming.)

setting.description: Before school. The librarian knows your name. She saves you the desk by the window.

narrative.text: Violin case in the corner. You need to practice for the recital, but the AP Chemistry exam is Friday.
You play violin for college apps, not love. But sometimes, when no one is listening, you play the piece Ba used to hum. The melody from home.

options.text: Chemistry first. The recital can wait.
options.internal_monologue: (You ace the practice problems. But your fingers itch for the strings.)

options.text: Play the violin. Just for ten minutes. Just for yourself.
options.internal_monologue: (The melody fills the empty library. For ten minutes, you're not a student. You're not a son. You're just a person making something beautiful.)

setting.description: Lunch. The table is split between people eating and people studying.

narrative.speaker: Dev
narrative.text: Dude, my parents want me to go to Johns Hopkins. Pre-med. I want to do computer science.
Dev stares at his sandwich. You recognize the weight in his voice. It's the same one you carry.

options.text: "Do CS. You'd be amazing at it."
options.internal_monologue: (Dev looks at you like you just gave him permission. You wonder who will give you the same.)

options.text: "Medicine is safe. Our parents know what they're talking about."
options.internal_monologue: (You hear your parents' voice coming out of your mouth. Dev hears it too. He nods. But something dims behind his eyes.)

setting.description: 11:30 PM. The house is dark. Light leaks from under your door.

narrative.text: You hear the front door. Ma is home from her second shift. She moves quietly, trying not to wake anyone.
Then: the soft clink of a bowl. She's warming up food for you. You can hear her footsteps approaching your door.

options.text: Open the door before she knocks
options.internal_monologue: (Ma's face. The surprise. Then the warmth. She sits with you while you eat. She doesn't say anything. She doesn't need to. You eat every grain of rice.)

options.text: Wait for her to leave the bowl and go to bed
options.internal_monologue: (You hear her set the bowl down. A pause. Then her footsteps retreating. The congee is cold by the time you eat it. It doesn't taste like anything.)

setting.description: College application season. The walls are covered with pennants from schools you can't name.

narrative.speaker: Counselor
narrative.text: Alex, your grades are strong. Your SAT is competitive. What schools are you looking at?
The list Ba typed up is in your pocket. Stanford. MIT. Harvard. The names he looked up when he first arrived in this country.

options.text: Read Ba's list. These are the right schools.
options.internal_monologue: (The counselor nods approvingly. 'Ambitious.' Ba would be proud of that word. You're not sure you are.)

options.text: "I've been thinking about schools with strong music programs too."
options.internal_monologue: (The counselor raises an eyebrow. 'That's... different from what I expected.' You think of Ba's list in your pocket. It feels heavier now.)

setting.description: After school. His room looks exactly like yours. Same textbooks. Same stress.

narrative.text: You're both studying. The silence is comfortable. This is what friendship looks like when you're 16 and carrying the weight of two generations.

narrative.speaker: Dev
narrative.text: Do you ever think about what happens if we don't get in? Like... anywhere good?

options.text: "We'll get in. We have to."
options.internal_monologue: (The 'have to' hangs in the air. You both know it's not about wanting.)

options.text: "Sometimes. And honestly? It terrifies me."
options.internal_monologue: (Dev puts down his textbook. 'Me too,' he says. And for a moment, the weight is halved because it's shared.)

setting.description: Ba is watching a documentary about engineering marvels. He turns it off when you walk in.

narrative.speaker: Ba
narrative.text: You are working too hard. Come sit.
Ba pats the couch next to him. He turns the TV back on. It's a bridge being built, beam by beam.

options.text: Sit with Ba and watch the bridge being built
options.internal_monologue: (Ba explains how the cables distribute weight. His eyes light up in a way you rarely see. For thirty minutes, he's not a taxi driver. He's Dr. Chen, structural engineer. You wish he could be that person all the time.)

options.text: "Can't, Ba. College apps are due soon."
options.internal_monologue: (Ba nods. 'Yes. Yes, go study.' He turns back to the bridge. The volume stays low. He's watching alone again.)

setting.description: Senior awards ceremony. The auditorium smells like floor wax and ambition.

narrative.text: They call your name for the Academic Excellence award. The applause is polite. Dev claps loudest.
From the stage, you can see the empty seats where parents are supposed to sit. Ma is working. Ba is driving.

options.text: Take a photo of the certificate to send to the family group chat
options.internal_monologue: (Ma sends 12 heart emojis. Ba sends a thumbs up. Lily sends 'ok nerd ü§ì'. You screenshot all three.)

options.text: Put it in your bag. They'll see it when they see it.
options.internal_monologue: (Awards feel different when nobody's watching you receive them.)

setting.description: After school. You almost never come here. Ma's apron is stained. Her hands are red.

narrative.text: Ma is carrying three plates at once. The owner is yelling something in the kitchen. She doesn't flinch.
She sees you and her face transforms. For one second, the exhaustion lifts.

narrative.speaker: Ma
narrative.text: Alex! Why you here? You should be studying! Sit, sit, I bring you something to eat.

options.text: Stay. Eat. Watch her work.
options.internal_monologue: (You eat the food she brings. It's the best thing on the menu ‚Äî the dish she only makes for family. Between orders, she sits with you for forty-five seconds at a time. Each time feels like a whole conversation.)

options.text: "I just wanted to say hi. I should get back to studying."
options.internal_monologue: (Ma's face flickers. 'Okay. You study hard.' She watches you leave through the kitchen window. You don't look back. If you did, you'd stay.)

setting.description: The last night before applications go out. Your desk is a battlefield of drafts.

narrative.text: The personal essay prompt stares back at you: 'Tell us about a challenge you've overcome.'
You think about Ba's engineering degree that means nothing here. Ma's hands cracked from dishwater. Lily's drawing of you in a graduation cap that's too big.
'We came here for you.' That sentence. Every choice you've made leads back to it.

options.text: Write about your parents' sacrifice. Make them the hero.
options.internal_monologue: (The essay writes itself. Adversity. Resilience. Gratitude. The admissions committee will love it. You wonder if reducing your parents' lives to 650 words is its own kind of betrayal.)

options.text: Write about the violin. The melody Ba used to hum. Finding yourself in music.
options.internal_monologue: (The essay is messy and honest and doesn't mention a single SAT score. You're not sure it's what they want to hear. But it's the first time you've written something true.)

setting.description: Three months later. The envelope is thick. Thick is good. Thick is good.

narrative.text: Ma, Ba, and Lily are standing behind you. Ma's hands are clasped. Ba is pretending to be calm. Lily is filming on her phone.
You open it.

options.text: Read the letter aloud
options.internal_monologue: (The college you got into depends on how you lived. The numbers matter. But so does the essay. So does the person who wrote it.)

narrative.text: Ma cries. Ba puts his hand on your shoulder. It's the most he's ever said.
Lily posts the video. The caption is just three emojis: üéìüí™‚ù§Ô∏è
That night, Ma makes your favorite. The whole family sits at the table. All four chairs are full.
You don't know it yet, but this is the last time all four chairs will be full for a long time.
